metadata.synopsis: Josie Geller (Drew Barrymore), a baby-faced junior copywriter at the Chicago Sun-Times, must pose as a student at her former high school to research contemporary teenage culture. With the help of her brother, Rob (David Arquette), Josie infiltrates the inner circle of the most popular clique on campus. But she hits a major snag in her investigation -- not to mention her own failed love life -- when she falls for her dreamy English teacher, Sam Coulson (Michael Vartan).

reviews: Attempts to tap into the sense of missed opportunity that one inevitably leaves high school with. Unfortunately, it fails to offer anything other than that same old crop of clichés.
Never Been Kissed remains one of the best teen movies and romcoms of the '90s, and a true ode to nerdy, overly enthusiastic girls of all ages.
"This is a very bad idea." Exacta-mundo, sister.
Never Been Kissed does very little to distinguish itself from the umpteen other high-school comedies we've seen this year.
This is one of those films that just doesn't know when to end.
[B]y and large she generates the kind of charm that, since Scream and Everyone Says I Love You, she's made her trademark.
Too bad the film, about a budding journalist assigned to do an expose on the degradations of high school life, simply isn't worthy of [Barrymore].
[T]hanks to Barrymore's captivating performance, a fun turn from David Arquette (as her slightly odd older brother) and a minor role for Leelee Sobieski, this is enjoyable fare.
A genuinely sweet and romantic story for teens.
Drew Barrymore's virtuoso performance smooths over the plot holes.
The most exhilarating American movie I have seen this year -- which isn't saying much.
The material is pretty much the same as She's All That and the other recent high school movies, but Barrymore has the big screen stuff to pull it off.
Barrymore again displays her remarkable ability to get the audience rooting for her singular blend of vulnerability and sunny optimism.
This is an okay date flick. It's somewhat forgettable, like high school should be, but possessing a few moments it'll be tough to get out of your head.
A surprisingly solid and entertaining teen flick
The less Never Been Kissed forces its material, the more enjoyable it is.
Barrymore demonstrates an acute sensitivity to the angst of adolescence, and handles it with kid gloves.
Have you noticed yet that there's really no point to this story?
The deft script and solid performances turn what could have been empty piffle into remarkably entertaining piffle that'll leave you smiling.
